blorr: Tools for building binary logistic regression models <img src="hex_blorr.png" align="right" />
------------

**Author:** [Aravind Hebbali]()<br/>
**License:** [MIT](https://opensource.org/licenses/MIT)

[![CRAN status](http://www.r-pkg.org/badges/version/blorr)](https://cran.r-project.org/package=blorr) [![Travis build status](https://travis-ci.org/rsquaredacademy/blorr.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/rsquaredacademy/blorr) [![AppVeyor Build Status](https://ci.appveyor.com/api/projects/status/github/rsquaredacademy/blorr?branch=master&svg=true)](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/rsquaredacademy/blorr) [![Coverage status](https://codecov.io/gh/rsquaredacademy/blorr/branch/master/graph/badge.svg)](https://codecov.io/github/rsquaredacademy/blorr?branch=master) ![](https://img.shields.io/badge/lifecycle-experimental-orange.svg)

blorr is designed to make it easier for users, particularly beginner/intermediate R users to build logistic regression models.

<br>

### Installation

You can install blorr from github with:

```{r gh-installation, eval = FALSE}
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("rsquaredacademy/blorr")
```

<br>

### Consistent Prefix

blorr uses consistent prefix `blr_*` for easy tab completion.

<br>

### Quick Overview

#### Introduction

```{r libs}
library(blorr)
library(magrittr)
```

```{r model}
# create model using glm
model <- glm(honcomp ~ female + read + science, data = hsb2,
             family = binomial(link = 'logit'))
```

<br>

#### Regression Output

```{r regress}
blr_regress(model)
```

<br>

#### Model Fit Statistics

```{r mfs}
blr_model_fit_stats(model)
```

<br>

#### Confusion Matrix

```{r conf}
blr_confusion_matrix(model)
```

<br>

#### Hosmer Lemeshow Test

```{r hoslem}
blr_hosmer_lemeshow_test(model)
```

<br>

#### Gains Table

```{r gains}
blr_gains_table(model)
```

<br>

#### ROC Curve

```{r roc}
model %>%
  blr_gains_table %>%
  blr_roc_curve
```

<br>

#### KS Chart

```{r kschart}
model %>%
  blr_gains_table %>%
  blr_ks_chart
```

<br>

#### Lorenz Curve

```{r}
blr_lorenz_curve(model)
```
